results.title: Handle with care: glass
results.creator_credit: Mohan Wadhwani, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A brief history of the Indian glass industry, contrasting the products of the individual artisan and the modern streamlined factory. To aid the industry, the Government established the Central Glass and ceramic Research Institute in Calcutta to conduct research into new types of glass.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mohan Wadhwani, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India

results.title: The Gunpowder Man
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Eastern Suburb's Children's Film Group
results.brief_description:
In this short film, made in 1966, two children build a Guy Fawkes statue, but are spotted by a third child who reveals their secret to their classmates. The children fight over the statue and eventually join forces to light the bonfire together.

The burning of a Guy Fawkes effigy is a tradition that emerged in the UK, initially to commemorate the failure of a plot, known as the Gunpowder Plot, to assassinate King James I in London on 5 November 1605. In its modern form, the tradition is celebrated as more of a social gathering, with a display of bonfires and fireworks. In Australia, it has become less common since the 1970s.

This short film was sponsored by the Eastern Suburbs Children’s Film Group, Melbourne, and produced and directed by John Richardson. Written by John Richardson and Val Fairweather. Featured cast include Christopher Wilson, Scott McClung, Christopher Ely, Robert Bartnik, Ian Mathieson, Daniel Meltzer, Stephen Palamountain and Jamie Steuart.

results.title: Community College Mt Gambier: growing
results.creator_credit: Justin Milne, New Films and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This is the story of the South East Community College Mount Gambier. Features two teachers, Bev Puckridge and Ian Winter, who narrate throughout the film. Shows how students go back to their own communities and set up and teach smaller groups in woodwork, pottery, spinning etc. Emphasis is made that art is a natural part of our world - a natural thing to do. It is not the finished product that really matters, but the thought process used to achieve it.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Justin Milne, New Films and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: Goodness - it's milk!
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit
results.brief_description:
This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, promotes the dairy industry by proclaiming the benefits of drinking milk.

The film opens with some lovely footage of a couple exploring the Blue Dandenongs, including a milkbar with signs for ‘Peter’s Ice-Cream’, ‘Herald’, and ‘Four ‘n’ Twenty Pies’, where they order two tall glasses of milk.

The film then shows scenes of schoolchildren, a patient and nurse in a hospital and a domestic kitchen, while the narrator describes the health benefits of milk. The film finishes with footage of the dairy industry, from the farm to industrial pasteurising and bottling processes, and finally home delivery.

results.title: Glassmakers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
A survey of the wide range of glass products manufactured by British craftsmen. Includes manufacture of plate glass and installation of a large sheet in one of the Festival of Britain buildings; making of stained glass windows; manufacture of optical glass and lenses; prisms and lanterns for lighthouses; production of electric light globes; glass blowing and making of nahd0made cut glass.

results.title: Fremantle cray fishers
results.brief_description: The departure of the cray fishing boats from Fremantle, Western Australia, in the early morning to the fishing grounds in the deep water. These hard working fishermen work a twelve hour day and are dependent on the weather and the mood of the sea for a good season. After the long day they return to port with their catch.

results.title: Dream
results.creator_credit: Arthur Cantrill, Corinne Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description: A partly animated film based on a series of drypoint prints (‘Movements’ and ‘Combats’) by Australian printmaker Charles Lloyd on the theme of aggression in society. The sound composition by Arthur Cantrill is a mix of percussion and altered piano (plucking and hitting strings and soundboard, played by Arthur Cantrill), sound effects (including breathing), and electronically modified children’s laughter, recorded on a Nagra reel to reel tape recorder and transferred to 16mm magnetic tracks which were laid and mixed in a professional sound studio, where reverberation was added to some sections.

results.title: Blue like an orange
results.brief_description: Puppets of the Orient and the Occident are presented in this UNESCO contribution to understanding between East and West. Scenes of puppet plays in India, Japan, Singapore, Malaysia, Laos, Poland, Czechoslovakia and the United States today. The presentations illustrate the great variety of the traditions which have survived for thousands of years. Also includes archival footage of Jim Henson and “the muppets” including a very early Kermit.
